segments.text: William Wooten, director of the Texas Transportation Institute.
Today's date is July the 30th.
Dr. Wooten, could we begin by, you're telling us something about your background.
Well, I was born out in the country, about 15 miles from the town of Junction, Texas, which is up in the hill country.
I went to school in Austin.
Well, it's northwest a little of Austin.
Kimball County, which is up on the Balcones Escarpment.
It's sheep and goat country, rush country.

Its nearest large town is probably closer to Kerrville than any other, and San Angelo was probably the major regional shopping center for that, if there was such a thing at that time, as a regional shopping center.
It was the place that people went to.
Do major trading.
That's there where some of those coal streams run through it.
Right, right.
I went to school and started in a little school that's no longer in existence at Teacup, Texas.
One word, Teacup.
Right, it's named after a little mountain that is...
looks like an inverted teacup, comes up with a little rim on top.
And there was a little two-room school there with a little store at that time.
And then went to a couple of years at London, which is about seven or eight miles away, and then finished up, I think, from the fifth grade on in Junction.
high school there and graduated from there in 1943.
We had a farm and ranch combined, let's say it was about 13, 14 miles out of junction.
You had cattle and sheep?
Cattle and sheep, primarily sheep and goats.
Sheep and goats, that's all brush country and it's sheep and goat country.
What memories do you have of the Depression as a boy?
I was still a little bit small when the major effects of the Depression came.
I was born in 26, and the Depression really started hitting, I guess, in 29 to 30.
My primary memories was a society totally without money in our area.
We almost reverted to a barter system.
during that period, cash crops or cash income was very hard to generate.
And we had no real severe problems other than those problems associated with having no money.
We always had plenty of food and plenty to eat and got by very well.
But it was a real experience looking back on it to see that you traded eggs or a calf or something else that you needed.
And it brought about, of course, as I guess most periods of adversity does, a pretty strong interdependence with your neighbors.

You shared, you killed a calf, and you split it up between various neighbors, and then they did the same when they, of course, at that time there was no refrigeration or anything, so there was a need to do that too.
But a lot of neighbor interaction, because everybody was in the same general condition of no money and plenty of food, just spread it around like that.
So it was...
It was a unique era to grow up in in that part of the world.
It was no major hardships, but looking back on it and looking at the complete lack of cash money, part of that country, in an attempt to develop cash, some sort of cash income,
Planted cotton, and of course that is a terrible area of the state to try to grow cotton up in those hills.
But it was just an attempt to try to generate something that would, to have something that would generate cash income.
It was unsuccessful.
Right.
If you could get a half a bale to the acre or a quarter of a bale to the acre, that was considered to be a pretty good crop.
And, of course, there's no cotton grown in that part of the world now.
But during that period of the Depression, there was a gin located about seven, eight miles away.
But we lived very well during the periods of the Depression.
Living without money is not all that bad if you

self-sustaining self-sustaining it quite well okay when you finished high school in 1943 what did you do then my first uh i had i have uh five four brothers there are five of us and of course world war ii was going on at that time and my first uh interest of course was getting into the service before the war was over and i didn't get to participate i had a brother who

who was flying B-24s at that time and I took a trip to Tarrant Field in Fort Worth where he was based at the time and went through a B-24 and I thought that was the greatest thing that I'd ever seen and the one thing for me to would be to be able to fly so I immediately
applied for the Air Force or at that time the Army Air Corps in San Antonio.

I took the physical examinations and all of the written tests that they provided at the time and then went back home to wait to see if I were going to be accepted and of course I was only 17 at the time so I
Went back to, they told me to come back, I believe, in two weeks, and I did.
And they said, oh, yeah, I'd passed all of the examinations, both physically and the written tests.
And I said, great, when do I go in?
And they said, well, we can't take you until you're 18.
Well, that was pretty disturbing.
So on the way out, this was in the, I believe they called it the post office building in San Antonio.

It was up on the second floor, as I recall, and as I was walking out very dejectedly from the Air Force Air Corps recruiting office, going down the hall, here was this other recruiting office with a Marine sergeant standing there with his blue uniform with the stripes down the trousers and all of the red insignia on his arms and
He said, what's the matter, son?
Wouldn't they take you in the Air Force?
And I said, oh, yeah, they'll take me, but I've got to wait until I'm 18.
And he said, well, have you ever thought about joining the Marine Corps?
And I said, well, no, I really hadn't because I want to fly.
He said, well, don't you know that the Marine Corps has the greatest Air Corps of all the services?
And I said, no, I really didn't.
I didn't know much about it.
He said, oh, yeah.
I said, we have the.
finest airplanes and the finest pilots and all of the services.
I said, well, that doesn't make any difference to me whether I fly for the Marine Corps or for the Army as long as I get to fly.

He said, well, come on in and I'll sign you up and I'll put on your papers that I said, of course, everybody has to go through boot camp when they go into the Marine Corps, but I'll put on your papers that you're going to go to flight school as soon as your boot camp's over.
Great, that's fine.
Well,
I didn't go immediately then.
I didn't enter until March the next year.
This was in October.
But when I did go in, I was almost through boot camp before I finally learned that the Marine Corps didn't have a pilot training program at all.
They got theirs out of the Navy.
So that's the way I got into the Marine Corps.
I was going in to fly and found out they didn't even have a pilot training program.
At that time, we were having some pretty strong needs in the South Pacific.
So when I went in, people were not staying in this country very long.
We went through our boot camp training, which they'd shortened, and then the period of combat conditioning in San Diego.
Our combat conditioning and programs, and then
we were immediately shipped out to the South Pacific.

I went on a troop ship from San Diego to Honolulu and was there about a month in what they called a replacement depot and then took a little, very small Danish freighter that they were using at the time to carry troops
from there to Guadalcanal.
And I went into Guadalcanal in about, oh gosh, I forget the dates, but it was sometime that summer.
Now, the island had already been secured before I got there.
So our only activities really were patrols, trying to mop up the remnants of the Japanese that were still there.
But the major fighting had already been completed by the time I got there.
We were on Guadalcanal for, and I'm not good at dates at all, but for a period of months.
And then went to Guam.
And they were in the process of retaking Guam then.
Again, I was with a third corps battalion, in which the first and sixth divisions were the major elements.
But we were with a specialized signal group.
We were called the Joint Assault and Signal Operations.
The first, the only real combat action that I was in was in Okinawa.
We were in the advanced landing parties on Okinawa.
We went in there, I believe it was Easter Sunday.
And again, I was still with the 3rd Corps, Special Signal Battalion with the 3rd Corps.

And we were the group that were to land with the assault troops and provide ship-to-shore communications with the landing, with the troop ships and with the support battle ships that were there in support of the landings.
I was on Okinawa all the way through until it was secured.
And again, the date sort of escaped me, but we left Okinawa to go back to Guam again.
And we were on an LST.
And we're still aboard ship.
when the atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima.
I think that was about August, the first part of August, the fourth or fifth of August.
So all we could do, all we did really was land back in Guam.
Stayed on shore probably a matter of just a week or 10 days while we were regrouping.
And we were a group, our group was sent to China
to North China then, and landed in North China at Tencent as a part of a force to repatriate the Japanese out of China.
They had been in China since, oh gosh, the early, I guess the late 30s, 39 or 40.
So our group went in to repatriate
As I understood it, the major concern was that once the Chinese learned that the war was over and Japan had surrendered, that they might just kill all the Japanese soldiers that were there.
So we were to go up and disarm the Japanese, accept their surrender, and then ship them home.
I said we landed in China on September the 1st, and then...
Stayed there, did the repatriation.
Stayed there until, oh, nearly, well, until June of the next year.
That must be June of 45.
So no, that'd be June of 46.
My years slipped.
June of 1946, I left China to come back to get discharged.
We were, of course, during that time, that was the, we got the Japanese out relatively early.
But that was the same time that Miao Tse-tung was coming down out of Manchuria on his move south.
And Chiang Kai-shek was supposedly fighting him all the way down, being pushed back into north China and eventually on out through Shanghai.
So we were a part of the truce teams that the United States sent to China during that period of late 45 to try to minimize the fighting between Chiang Kai-shek and Mao Tse-Tung.
We were...
The two major cities in that part of North China were Tencent and Peking.
Peking being the old national capital.
And one of our little chores was to protect the Peking-Tencent Railroad, which during this period, and the Chinese, the communist nationalists were right in that area during this period.
And the railroad got
its brunt of the action.
They'd attack the trains and burn the ties and stack up a bunch of the ties and put the rails on top and melt them down.
It made it very inconvenient to operate a railroad.
But it really wasn't a pitch battle sort of thing during that period.
So that's sort of a brief term.
I spent all of the time that I was in the Marine Corps in the South Pacific and China, and very little of it in the United States.
In fact, I came back, landed, and I think was discharged within a week.
So my tour in the service spent in this country, I think, lasted about two months out of the three years that I was in.
I wasn't here very long.
You were discharged when?
In June, I think, 29th or so of 1946.
By how much time do you think that the bombing shortened the war against Japan?
Substantially.
I'm not a military historian, but we were, of course, getting prepared, and the reason we were going back to Guam was that was to be our staging area
regroup and get rearmed and outfitted supposedly for the attack on the Japanese mainland.
And it would have been both a very bloody affair and a very prolonged affair.
Because the Japanese in the latter stages of the war had learned how to fight our style.
The campaigns had become progressively more costly.
Okinawa was a terrific loss on, of course, both on the Japanese side and on ours.
It was a very, very bloody campaign.
And had we had to move into the Japanese mainland, they are a very tough,
people, and they would have been very hard to dislodge through conventional warfare means.
Now, whether some other event might have precipitated a surrender or whether they might have seen the handwriting on the wall and surrendered anyway, nobody knows, but...
It took more than one.
It took more than one, that's right.
When you got out of the service in 46, what did you do then?
This doesn't sound very good from a standpoint of A&M's recruiting.
But while I was in the Marine Corps, I grew up with our closest neighbor.
He had a boy about a year older than I am.
He and I went through high school together, went through the Marine Corps together.
He was in the 11th.
Marines, which was a field artillery unit.
We served in the South Pacific and in China together.
And while we were in China, knowing that we were going to be discharged, we decided that we were going home to school when we got back home.
So we, of course, got to talking about where we would go.
We decided we'd go to the same place.

Frankly, we weren't very knowledgeable about universities, having come from a small country community during the Depression years, but we had listened to Southwest Conference football, and we knew about Texas A&M, about the University of Texas, and about TCU.
At that time, that was the
or just prior to that time.
Of course, they had Sammy Ball and Kai Aldrich at TCU, who were very famous football players and made quite a name for the school.
So it had narrowed down to those three places.

And we finally decided that, well, since TCU was a private school and neither one of us had any money at all, that we were going to have to go to one of the state schools, which was either Texas or A&M.
So in a 10-cent bar one night, we decided we'd make our decision.
And it came down to flipping a coin.
As the heads would go to Texas, tails would come to A&M.
And it came up tails.
We both came to A&M in the fall of 46.
And we got discharged about the same time.
He got out a little earlier than I did.
But we both hitchhiked a ride down here.
about 250 miles, back of a pickup with their sea bags, and entered A&M with that big entering class that came in in the fall of 46, the returning veterans.
You didn't have to go through the COA program here since you were a veteran.
I didn't have to go through it.
They had a, well, let me tell you, when we got here, you probably don't recall, but at the time, this was a big influx of,
of returning veterans.
They didn't have housing on campus for us.
So they put us at the old Bryan Air Force Base in the tar paper shacks.
And our ride had left us on campus.
We had registered and signed up and gone through all of the enrollment procedures.
Then we said, naturally, well, now where do we live?
And they said, well, there'll be a truck come by and take you to your barracks.
It's going to be out at Bryan Air Force Base.
We didn't know where that was.
We found out it was about 12 miles out of town.
We got out there, and it was the same thing we'd just gotten out of, you know, with the military environment, those old tar paper shacks.
And they really were tar paper.
And we got there late in the afternoon, about sundown.
And we were both ready to check it out and go home.
Unfortunately, we didn't have any transportation since we'd hitchhiked down here.
So we decided that it was really sort of dumb to pick up our sea bags and try to hitchhike a ride back home again that night, so we'd wait until tomorrow.
Well, obviously, all the rest of the fellas got in the barracks, and we got to know each other, and by the next morning, things looked a whole lot better, and so we stayed.
But we spent the first year out there, all of the instructions out there.
Again, now this was in 46, and there was practically no transportation.
In our barracks of, I don't remember, 35, 40 people probably in that one barracks, maybe more, there was one old car that one of the fellows had.
And that was the total transportation availability in our barracks.
And the rest of them were about the same, very little transportation.
which meant if you were at Bryan Air Force Base with no transportation, you were pretty well isolated.
So we were reasonably well isolated out there for the first year.
Moved back on campus then in 47.
Lived up at what was called the new dorm area at that time, the old dorms up at Northgate.
I think we were in 17.
And stayed there then that year.
And then we had the program that...
If you were returning veteran, you didn't have to take the first two years of you didn't have to take any of the military corps.
But if you wanted to get a commission, you could then go into the core in your junior year and go under contract and become commissioned.
Well, I wasn't
at all sure of what the future military positions would be.
And I knew if we ever had another war, I'd already fought one as a private and PFC.
And I had seen that officers did a whole lot better than enlisted men in the service.
And if we ever had another one, I was going to be an officer this time.
So I went through the core.
I joined the core in my junior year was in
EVET Air Force.
And we had a veteran battalion.
And I went through and was commissioned when I graduated in 1950 in the Air Force as a second lieutenant in the Air Force.
Majored in agricultural economics and stayed here, then went on to graduate school.
after I graduated, not totally because I had the burning desire for additional knowledge, but jobs were awful scarce.
And the assistantship that I had in agricultural economics was about as good an offer as I had from a standpoint of money at that time.
It was 1950, and jobs were not all that plentiful at that time.
So you got a master's in this stuff?

I got a master's in ag economics in what they called their ag administration option in 1951 and then worked for Dr. John McNeely, who was a livestock marketing specialist in the agricultural economics area.
I'd worked for him.
while I was an undergraduate and also under my master's, getting my master's, and stayed on then working for the station, experiment station full time until about March of 1953.
We were doing livestock auction studies.
We did efficiency studies, marketing studies of livestock auctions, designed new auction systems, and so forth.
Very interesting work.
Had an opportunity to go to New York City with a private firm, price forecasting firm, called Industrial Commodity Corporation.
Left here in March of 53.
Went to New York City.
Took my wife and little baby.
Pulled a trailer up there.
When did you marry?
Oh, I got married in 1950.
I got married between the time that classes were out and graduation in 1950.
Where's your wife from?
She was from a little town in Menard, which was the next town over from Junction.
I've heard of Menard.
Yeah, well, it's the suburb of Junction.
It's one of the little towns about the same size as Junction.
Okay, then you went to New York in 1953, right?
The Industrial Commodity Corporation was a very, again, I've been very fortunate.
I've had some very interesting jobs in my life.
This was a private forecasting firm.
It had been founded by the president of the company, Mr. Jay Carvel Lang, who had gotten into the business and developed some forecasting, crash forecasting techniques.

and had worked for, had gotten contracts with Colgate-Palmolive-Pete at that time, it was a Colgate company, to do their inventory control work, as we'd tell them when to buy and stock up on the materials used in making soaps and toothpaste, and when to let the inventory go down.
It was an expectation of falling prices in the future.
Well, I was hired to set up a livestock and livestock product section since my background was in livestock.
We did the economic forecast for Time Life Fortune magazines and then did procurement advice for major companies.
In my case, I did procurement work or
telling them when to buy or when to sell, depending on what kind of company it was.
For example, Armor was one of our clients, Armor Packing Company, and we would tell them when to sell their animal byproducts, particularly tallow and lard and hides.
And we also were on the other side of the market with
The Trostall Tanneries in Indianapolis was another large client.
We'd tell them when to buy ahead on hides for their tanning, leather-making industries.
But when we moved to New York, I was hired by a fellow named John Atkins who was originally from Tennessee and had been with the firm about a year.
And they lived out on Long Island.
Is that ADK or ATK?
ATK, Atkins.
As a part of, of course, I told him, you know, I don't know anything about New York.
I've never been there.
I really didn't have any desire to go to New York and didn't know anything about the area.
So I asked him to see if he could locate a house for us.
He did in a little town of Bellmore.
B-E-L-L-M-O-R-E.
Now, Belmore is out on Long Island, on the Long Island Railroad.
And it's way out on the island.
When we moved there in 53, it was a typical little German community.
Large oak and wild cherry trees, a very beautiful little place.
It was in the midst of a farming area.
And if you'll recall at one time, Long Island potatoes were the classic potato, the big potato area.
Also strawberries, a very rich farming area out there.
It's now covered with houses from shore to shore.
But we lived in this little town.
He'd gotten us a very nice house.
We had no furniture, of course.
The first six months that we lived there, but it's gradually accumulated furniture.
My wife liked it very much.
It was a very, very nice place.
Unfortunately, it was a long way from where I worked in downtown New York City.
Our offices were at 122 East 42nd Street, which is right in the middle of downtown New York City.
right across from the Chrysler Building.
It was in a place called the Shannon Building.
It was C-H-A-N-N-I-N, I believe.
So I would catch the 6.59 train every morning in order to get, or 7 o'clock train, it was a 6.59 just before 7, to get to work at 9.
So I had about a two-hour commute each way every day.
And I'd ride the Long Island Railroad into Times Square.
What was the fare on that railroad back then?
Do you recall?
I bought monthly tickets, monthly pass sort of thing.
And it was about $30-something, $36 a month, which meant if you bought a regular ticket, it would be, say, a dollar-something each way.
which in those days, and I was making, by the way, when I went there, I made $5,000.
That was my starting salary, $5,000 a year.
So $2 a day for railroad fare on a $5,000 salary is a substantial lick, substantial cost, in addition to the time required.
We'd go into time to the Long Island Railroad.
We'd go into Times Square.
We'd...
get out, walk over, and catch the shuttle from Times Square to Grand Central Station, and then get out and walk to work.
And masses of people everywhere.
I had a very interesting time getting used to that many people, and particularly the crowding on both the Long Island Railroad and the subways.
It was a unique experience.
Was that same railroad still running each way there?
Yeah, still running.
probably still with the same equipment.
It was old equipment even then, but they're probably still using much of the same equipment.
So y'all decided to move out of Long Island?
Then, right, we, after being there about two years, we had a, our daughter was born in New York shortly after we got there, or on Long Island, and I woke up
One day, with not only the commute schedule, but I traveled quite a bit.
I was to see clients out in Indianapolis or Chicago or all over the country.
Since the livestock area, most of it was in the Midwest.
So I was out of town quite a bit.
And two, I found that my kids were still asleep every morning when I left to go to work.
And I didn't get back until after 7 at night, so oftentimes or later.
And oftentimes, they were still asleep when I got in.
So I wasn't seeing my family any.
And so I decided to move about that hour.
I was in the frame of mind to be approached to move somewhere else.
And about that time, the
12 western states decided that they would set up a price forecasting operation to serve the feeder cattle industry for the 12 western states based in Denver.
So Dr. McNeely, who I'd worked under here since

What I was doing in New York was developing price forecasting techniques using, at that time, a relatively new tool of regression analysis, which we'd sort of developed and refined to do price forecasting.
And I had a good rationale for it.
I asked if I would be interested in moving to Denver and being

Assistant Director of the 12th Regional Livestock Marketing Technical Committee, I believe it had a very short name to it, with a fellow named, who was director, named Harold Abel, who was a USDA employee.
So we did.
In fact, by that time, I had my salary in New York had increased
substantially, and I was making about between $12,000 and $13,000 a year, which is a very good salary then.
So I took a cut to about $8,000 to move from New York back to Denver.
So we moved across country again, left there in the spring of 1955.
Is that right?
Yeah.
Yeah.
spring of 55 and moved to Denver and set up the price forecasting mechanism for western feeder cattle.
As a part of that, we worked with the agricultural experiment stations of each of the 12 western states.
At that time, Texas was not a member of the western states, so it was always the
12 western states and Texas.
The line went down just to the west of us, but Texas was in the group.
Again, very interesting arrangement because the activity, which was housed in the Federal Building in Denver, was really funded through assessments to each one of the egg experiment stations.
Every state's got its different laws.
Some of them could put the money in a common pot.
Others couldn't.
They had to pay direct, either for travel or personnel costs.
So we might end up one month with a paycheck from Utah and the next time with one from Wyoming or Montana or Idaho as to where our money would come from.
Each month, but it all came out even in the end, but it was very interesting the way they had to go around and accumulate the funds to pay that sort of a program.
Stayed there a year.
We like Denver very much.
Except it stays cold.
Too long in the springtime for our tastes.
So in one of the.
trips back to Texas.
We came back down here to visit people here and happened to be in the ag economics department one day.
And Dr. Tim, who was head then, asked me if I knew Fred Benson.
I told him, no, I really didn't.
He was over here in engineering.
He said, well, they were
starting a new program called the Texas Transportation Institute and that he was looking for someone to head up a new research project that they had funded for the coming year.
So I came over and talked to Fred and then to Mr. McDonald, Thomas McDonald, who was the supposed head of the institute at that time.
It was sort of a
an arrangement that they brought him down to set it up, and he was to be the principal brain trust behind the institute.
But Mr. Benson was actually the one doing the actual administration of it.
So I visited with them.
We left and went back to Denver.
And in about a week, I got a letter from them offering me a job here.
Well, I'd taken a substantial cut in salary to move from New York to Denver, and I was offered a job at another cut in salary to move back to Texas A&M.
Fred offered me $7,000 a year.
At that time, I was making about
$8,600 in Denver.
Well, I knew that I wasn't going to get much more than that.
But I held out for a month or so to make it an even $7,200 or $600 a month.
And I never did get it.
I never could sway them for the extra $200.
And finally, we moved back here in April of 56.
And I've been here with it ever since.
You came in what capacity?
What was your exact title when you came in 55, 56?
I was associate research economist.
Now, one of the reasons I came was I wanted to go ahead and finish a Ph.D.
When I say finished one, I hadn't started it, but I wanted, well, I had taken a course or two, but I hadn't started the formal program.
So as a part of the negotiations was the fact that if I came, that I would be allowed to take one course a semester, which is now sort of a standard practice.
It wasn't all that standard at the time.
toward a PhD so that I could get, accumulate some of my coursework, get most of my coursework off and then drop back perhaps to half time or something and write a dissertation.
Well, I was, my title was Associate Research Economist.
So, and I was brought down specifically to head up a research project, what they called Customer Requirements in Transportation.
At Mr. McDonald's insistence, he had been chief of the Bureau of Public Roads for 34 years and was really considered to be the father of transportation in the country at that time.
One of his major concerns were that we were not really gearing our transportation systems to the needs of the users, that we were really
more concerned with the providers than we were with the users.
He wanted a continuing study of what do the users need?
What are their requirements for transportation?
And how are these requirements being met?
And how can then the providers of transportation more adequately adjust their systems to serve the real needs of the users?
That was one of the first studies that was done under our cooperative research program with the Highway Department, which funding came from the Highway Department to do that.
It was the study number two.
At that time, they called it Research Project 2.
RP2 was the title of it.
And I stayed... Well, we sort of...

need to change tapes this one on for again my i'm not real good at dates but probably two or three years we built and added some other research projects to it and the time that when i came here we were located in this building but the building was practically vacant there were about
four or five of us in this building.
And the building didn't look like it does now.
All of this area was our library.
All of this wing here was a library, which we've since cut up, made my office and the office next to it and a group of offices on the other side.
Upstairs, the area just above this was a big, what at that time they called a map room.

Now, the idea when they created the institute, and creation was through the efforts of Mr. DeWitt Greer, who was head of the highway department, Mr. Gib Gilchrist, who was chancellor of the system at that time, and Mr. McDonald.
And their concept was that this would be a think tank
a think tank operation that they'd bring Mr. McDonald and they would get a leading man from each of the disciplines in and they would really not have much to do except study and write and

evaluate policies of transportation and that their vision was in order to do this you needed to have room where you could spread out maps of the system and look at the way the systems came together and what the problems were and this sort of thing.
It never did work that way.
One, there was no funding available for that sort of thing.
So we
rather rapidly shifted over to more of a research orientation as opposed to a think tank funded policy group.
And in later years began modifying the building to accommodate those different kinds of needs.
The great big rooms, the map rooms, and so forth were not functionally useful.
The institute started, as I say, with only a few people.
It was actually created in 55, September 55, so I was here pretty early on in its life.
It was created by board minute order and through a special legislative provision which allowed the highway department.
